segments.en: Hello, everyone, and welcome to EnglishPod.
My name is Marco.
My name is Catherine, and today we're talking about someone who's very, very dirty.
segments.cn: 我叫Catherine，今天我们要谈论一个非常肮脏的人。

segments.en: That's right.
And actually, not only are we talking about something being dirty, but also that we want to clean everything.
segments.cn: 实际上，我们不仅在谈论肮脏的东西，还想要清理一切。

segments.en: Okay, so you'll learn how to call someone who likes clean things in English today.
segments.cn: 好的，今天你将学习如何用英语称呼喜欢干净事物的人。

segments.en: Let's take a listen to our dialogue.
segments.cn: 让我们来听听我们的对话。

segments.en: Ugh, this bathroom is a pigsty.
segments.cn: 哎，这个浴室真是一团糟。

segments.en: Helen, why do you keep flushing the toilet?
What's wrong?
I just can't stand it.
It's really gross in here.
There's a stain on the toilet seat, and the floor was wet and slippery, so I cleaned it.
segments.cn: 马桶座上有污渍，地板又湿又滑，所以我清理了一下。

segments.en: You did what?
Helen, I know it's gross, but I've seen many public washrooms that are much worse.
segments.cn: Helen，我知道这很恶心，但我见过很多公共洗手间更糟。

segments.en: Why are you cleaning the countertop?
Are you out of your mind?
I can't help myself.
It's just so disgusting in here.
Helen, this is not like your own bathroom.
segments.cn: Helen，这里可不是你自己的浴室。

segments.en: Just leave it to the cleaners, okay?
segments.cn: 还是交给清洁工吧，好吗？

segments.en: Hang on, I'm just going to quickly wipe this sink and sweep the floor.
segments.cn: 等一下，我只是快速擦一下水槽，扫一下地。

segments.en: You're such a neat freak.
I'm out of here.
Alright, we're back.
So this girl was very much of a neat freak, and we're going to take a look at that word a little bit later on.
segments.cn: 所以这个女孩真的是个洁癖，我们稍后会看看这个词。

segments.en: Why don't we go back to the very beginning and take a look at some vocab on language takeaway.
segments.cn: 为什么我们不回到一开始，看看一些语言要点。

segments.en: Language takeaway.
The first word we have here on language takeaway today is pigsty.
segments.cn: 今天语言要点的第一个词是“猪圈”。

segments.en: Right, this bathroom is a pigsty.
segments.cn: 对，这个浴室真是一团糟。

segments.en: Okay, so pigsty is a place where pigs live.
segments.cn: 好的，猪圈是猪生活的地方。

segments.en: Okay, so now this obviously, the bathroom is not really a place where pigs live.
segments.cn: 好的，显然，这个浴室并不是猪生活的地方。

segments.en: So if you call something a pigsty, you're saying that it's very... Dirty.
segments.cn: 所以如果你称某物为猪圈，你是在说它非常……肮脏。

segments.en: You're saying it's disgusting.
It's very, very dirty.
Like a pigsty.
So actually, if you go to a farm and you see where all the pigs are, that is actually called a pigsty.
segments.cn: 实际上，如果你去农场，看到所有的猪，那地方就叫做猪圈。

segments.en: Right, there's mud and dirt.
Yeah, that's a pigsty.
So someone who is very, very dirty you can also call a pig.
segments.cn: 所以一个非常肮脏的人你也可以称为猪。

segments.en: Okay, now she was saying that the bathroom is so dirty and it's really gross in here.
segments.cn: 好的，现在她说浴室太脏了，这里真的很恶心。

segments.en: Okay, so gross means something is...
segments.cn: 好的，恶心意味着某物是……

segments.en: She doesn't like it.
It's really dirty and, you know, makes her uncomfortable.
segments.cn: 这里真的很脏，让她感到不舒服。

segments.en: So something that doesn't taste good, you can say it's gross.
segments.cn: 所以某些味道不好，你可以说它很恶心。

segments.en: That's right.
So I don't like to eat snake.
I think eating snake is gross.
Okay, very good.
So something that is gross is something that's not really nice.
segments.cn: 所以恶心的东西是不太好的东西。

segments.en: Maybe it tastes bad or it smells bad.
segments.cn: 也许味道不好或闻起来不好。

segments.en: Something that is bad in general.
That's right.
Okay, so she went on to talk about the toilet seat and that there was a stain on the toilet seat.
segments.cn: 好的，她接着谈到马桶座上有污渍。

segments.en: Okay, a stain is usually a bad thing.
It means that there's a color or a Mark that's permanent or maybe can be washed away on something.
segments.cn: 这意味着某物上有颜色或标记，可能是永久的，或者可以被洗掉。

segments.en: So in this case the toilet seat has a Mark on it.
segments.cn: 所以在这种情况下，马桶座上有一个标记。

segments.en: Maybe it's brown or yellow.
But I can also say I was drinking wine and I spilled the wine on my shirt and it left a stain.
segments.cn: 但我也可以说我在喝酒，酒洒在我的衬衫上，留下了污渍。

segments.en: So now there's always this red part on my shirt.
segments.cn: 所以现在我的衬衫上总是有这个红色的部分。

segments.en: It won't go away.
Okay, so a stain is a Mark that usually won't go away.
segments.cn: 好的，所以污渍是一个通常不会消失的标记。

segments.en: Okay, so then she went on to describe the bathroom as being disgusting.
segments.cn: 好的，然后她继续形容这个浴室是令人厌恶的。

segments.en: So I guess this is very similar to gross.
segments.cn: 所以我想这与恶心非常相似。

segments.en: That's right.
Something that is gross is usually also disgusting.
segments.cn: 恶心的东西通常也是令人厌恶的。

segments.en: I can say, ugh, this food is awful.
segments.cn: 我可以说，哎，这食物真糟糕。

segments.en: It's just disgusting.
Okay.
But I can also say in this case, ugh, your room is disgusting.
segments.cn: 但我也可以在这种情况下说，哎，你的房间真恶心。

segments.en: You need to clean it.
It's so dirty or bad or unappealing.
segments.cn: 这里太脏了，或者说不好，或者不吸引人。

segments.en: So something that is gross, something that is disgusting is something negative.
segments.cn: 所以恶心的东西，令人厌恶的东西是负面的东西。

segments.en: Okay.
And then we have our keyword and the title of this lesson for today.
segments.cn: 然后我们有今天这节课的关键词和标题。

segments.en: A Neat Freak.
Her friend says, you're such a neat freak.
segments.cn: 她的朋友说，你真是个洁癖。

segments.en: That's right.
So a neat freak is someone who likes things to be very clean.
segments.cn: 所以洁癖是指喜欢事物非常干净的人。

segments.en: Okay.
And so a neat freak does not live in a pigsty.
segments.cn: 所以洁癖不住在猪圈里。

segments.en: Right.
A neat freak does not like to be in pigsties.
segments.cn: 洁癖不喜欢待在猪圈里。

segments.en: A neat freak likes things to be in order and organized and clean.
segments.cn: 洁癖喜欢事物有序、整洁和干净。

segments.en: So maybe somebody that's cleaning all the time or that's very, very organized, you can say that that person is a neat freak.
segments.cn: 所以也许总是清理或者非常有条理的人，你可以说那个人是洁癖。

segments.en: He is a neat freak or she is a neat freak.
segments.cn: 他是个洁癖，或者她是个洁癖。

segments.en: Now it's not necessarily a good thing to be a neat freak, but it's not terrible either to call somebody a neat freak.
segments.cn: 现在，成为洁癖不一定是好事，但称某人为洁癖也不是坏事。

segments.en: You can say, hey, are you a neat freak?
segments.cn: 你可以说，嘿，你是个洁癖吗？

segments.en: Right.
That means, are you really concerned about cleanliness?
segments.cn: 这意味着你真的很关心清洁吗？

segments.en: Uh-huh.
Okay.
Very good.
So a lot of great vocab.
segments.cn: 所以有很多很棒的词汇。

segments.en: Why don't we take a look again at our dialogue and we'll be back in a bit.
segments.cn: 我们再看看我们的对话，稍后再回来。

segments.en: Ugh, this bathroom is a pigsty.
segments.cn: 哎，这个浴室真是一团糟。

segments.en: Helen, why do you keep flushing the toilet?
What's wrong?
I just can't stand it.
It's really gross in here.
There's a stain on the toilet seat and the floor was wet and slippery, so I cleaned it.
segments.cn: 马桶座上有污渍，地板又湿又滑，所以我清理了一下。

segments.en: You did what?
Helen, I know it's gross, but I've seen many public washrooms that are much worse.
segments.cn: 海伦，我知道这很恶心，但我见过很多公共洗手间更糟。

segments.en: Why are you cleaning the countertop?
Are you out of your mind?
I can't help myself.
It's just so disgusting in here.
Helen, this is not like your own bathroom.
segments.cn: 海伦，这里可不是你自己的浴室。

segments.en: Just leave it to the cleaners, okay?
segments.cn: 还是交给清洁工吧，好吗？

segments.en: Hang on.
I'm just going to quickly wipe the sink and sweep the floor.
segments.cn: 我只是快速擦一下水槽，扫一下地。

segments.en: You're such a neat freak.
I'm out of here.
Alright, we're back, so now let's take a look at Fluency Builder.
segments.cn: 好吧，我们回来了，现在来看看流利构建器。

segments.en: Fluency Builder.
So the first thing we want to talk about today is this phrase, I can't stand it.
segments.cn: 今天我们想谈的第一句话是，我受不了。

segments.en: So this is our neat freak talking.
segments.cn: 这是我们的洁癖在说话。

segments.en: She says, I just can't stand it.
I just can't stand it.
So if you can't stand something, that means that you can't tolerate it.
segments.cn: 所以如果你受不了某件事，那就意味着你无法容忍它。

segments.en: That's right.
It means I don't like it, I don't want it, I don't want it anymore.
segments.cn: 这意味着我不喜欢它，我不想要它，我不想再要它。

segments.en: I need to change it.
Okay, so for example, if a bar is too loud, you say, I have to leave.
segments.cn: 好吧，比如说，如果酒吧太吵，你会说，我得走了。

segments.en: I can't stand it.
It's too loud in there.
That's right.
Or if you are next to me all day and you do, tap, tap, tap, tap, tap with your pen, I say, Marco, stop it.
segments.cn: 或者如果你整天在我旁边，用你的笔不停地敲打，我会说，马尔科，停下。

segments.en: I can't stand it anymore.
Okay, very good.
And then she went on to explain or to justify why she was cleaning the public restroom.
segments.cn: 然后她继续解释或辩解她为什么要清理公共洗手间。

segments.en: And she said, I can't help myself.
It's just too disgusting in here.
I can't help myself.
So this means that I cannot control my actions.
segments.cn: 这意味着我无法控制我的行为。

segments.en: Okay, I cannot control what I do.
segments.cn: 好吧，我无法控制我所做的事情。

segments.en: And so in some cases, like with a neat freak, the person really needs everything to be clean.
segments.cn: 在某些情况下，比如洁癖的人，确实需要一切都保持干净。

segments.en: And so she says, I can't help myself.
segments.cn: 所以她说，我控制不住自己。

segments.en: I have to clean.
Okay, so it's a phrase like this.
segments.cn: 好吧，这就是这样的一个短语。

segments.en: Don't try to separate it.
Don't try to separate it and try to define what help and help yourself.
segments.cn: 不要试图分开它并定义什么是帮助和帮助自己。

segments.en: It's more of a phrase saying, I can't control myself.
segments.cn: 这更像是一个短语，表示我无法控制自己。

segments.en: I can't control my actions.
I can't help myself.
Or in the case of another person, you say, she can't help herself.
segments.cn: 或者在另一个人的情况下，你会说，她控制不住自己。

segments.en: He can't help himself.
Right, so maybe you like to smoke and you're smoking all the time and you say, stop smoking.
segments.cn: 对，所以也许你喜欢抽烟，你一直在抽烟，你会说，停止抽烟。

segments.en: You say, I can't help myself.
segments.cn: 你会说，我控制不住自己。

segments.en: I have to smoke.
Yeah, I have to smoke.
Okay, and for our last phrase, she said, hang on.
segments.cn: 好吧，最后一句，她说，等一下。

segments.en: I'm just going to quickly wipe the sink and sweep the floor.
segments.cn: 我只是快速擦一下水槽，扫一下地。

segments.en: Hang on.
This means, wait a moment.
Yeah, so this is a really common phrase we hear in English.
segments.cn: 是的，这在英语中是一个非常常见的短语。

segments.en: It's something that you'll hear all the time in a pretty relaxed environment.
segments.cn: 这是你在比较轻松的环境中会经常听到的。

segments.en: Not maybe in school, but if someone says, okay, I'm going to go see you later and the other person wants to say something to you, you say, hang on.
segments.cn: 可能在学校不太会，但如果有人说，好吧，我要去见你，另一个人想对你说什么，你会说，等一下。

segments.en: Hang on.
Wait a moment.
I have to tell you this thing.
So you wouldn't really use it with your boss or a customer.
segments.cn: 所以你不会真的在你的老板或客户面前使用它。

segments.en: You wouldn't say, hang on a second.
No, you would say that with a friend or family member, things like that.
segments.cn: 不，你会和朋友或家人这样说。

segments.en: Okay, so it's a very informal way of saying, wait a moment, wait a minute.
segments.cn: 好吧，这是一种非常非正式的说法，表示，等一下，等一会儿。

segments.en: That's right.
So the formal way is, please wait.
segments.cn: 所以正式的说法是，请等一下。

segments.en: Please wait.
And the informal way is, hang on.
segments.cn: 非正式的说法是，等一下。

segments.en: Hang on, or hang on a sec, which is hang on a second.
segments.cn: 等一下，或者等一下，等一秒，这就是等一下。

segments.en: All right, that's all the words we have for today.
segments.cn: 好吧，今天我们就到这里。

segments.en: Why don't we review our dialogue one last time?
segments.cn: 我们再复习一次对话吧？

segments.en: This bathroom is a pigsty.
Helen, why do you keep flushing the toilet?
segments.cn: 海伦，你为什么一直冲马桶？

segments.en: What's wrong?
I just can't stand it.
It's really gross in here.
There's a stain on the toilet seat and the floor was wet and slippery.
segments.cn: 马桶座上有污渍，地板又湿又滑。

segments.en: So I cleaned it.
You did what?
Helen, I know it's gross, but I've seen many public washrooms that are much worse.
segments.cn: 海伦，我知道这很恶心，但我见过很多公共洗手间更糟。

segments.en: Why are you cleaning the countertop?
Are you out of your mind?
I can't help myself.
It's just so disgusting.
It's disgusting in here.
Helen, this is not like your own bathroom.
segments.cn: 海伦，这里可不是你自己的浴室。

segments.en: Just leave it to the cleaners, okay?
segments.cn: 还是交给清洁工吧，好吗？

segments.en: Hang on, I'm just going to quickly wipe the sink and sweep the floor.
segments.cn: 等一下，我只是快速擦一下水槽，扫一下地。

segments.en: You're such a neat freak.
I'm out of here.
All right, so talking about cleanliness and being neat, what type of person are you?
segments.cn: 好吧，谈谈清洁和整洁，你是什么样的人？

segments.en: Do you usually, are you a neat freak?
Do you keep everything very clean and ordered?
segments.cn: 你会把一切都保持得非常干净和有序吗？

segments.en: I'm not a neat freak, but I'm also not a pig.
segments.cn: 我不是洁癖，但我也不是猪。

segments.en: Not a slob.
I like things to be very organized.
segments.cn: 我喜欢东西非常有条理。

segments.en: Okay.
But I'm not really concerned about cleaning so much.
I'm too lazy.
So there's a difference for me.
In my house, I know where everything is, but maybe there's clothes on the floor and there's books in the bathroom.
segments.cn: 在我家，我知道一切在哪里，但可能地上有衣服，浴室里有书。

segments.en: So I'm in the middle.
What about you?
Are you a neat freak?
No, I'm not really a neat freak per se, but I do like everything to be very clean on the other hand.
segments.cn: 不，我并不算是爱整洁的人，但另一方面我确实喜欢一切都很干净。

segments.en: So I can't really stand it when things are... If things are out of order a little bit, that's okay, but if things are dirty, that really gets to me.
segments.cn: 所以当东西有点乱的时候，我可以接受，但如果东西脏了，那真的让我受不了。

segments.en: But I'm not the type of person that has, you know, folders with all my bills in one folder or labels or even when I was in school, I didn't have my notebooks in order.
segments.cn: 但我不是那种会把所有账单放在一个文件夹里，或者有标签的人，甚至在学校时，我的笔记本也没有按顺序放好。

segments.en: Really?
So we're the opposite.
Yeah, exactly.
But I hate things that are dirty.
Interesting.
Well, let us know, are you a neat freak?
segments.cn: 好吧，让我们知道，你是个爱整洁的人吗？

segments.en: Our website is EnglishPod.com.
You can talk about yourself all over that lesson comments area.
segments.cn: 你可以在那节课的评论区谈论自己。

segments.en: That's right.
And if you have any other suggestions or comments, we're always there as well.
segments.cn: 如果你有其他建议或评论，我们也一直在这里。

segments.en: And we'll see you guys next time.
Bye.
Bye.
